node.text:
Today's #MoodBoosterMonday celebrates Rosie and the incredible work her not-for-profit foundation, @coming.up.rosies, has done since she and her family founded it five years ago. 

When Rosie was nearly three years old, she was diagnosed with alopecia, an autoimmune disease that attacks hair follicles and prevents hair growth, resulting in baldness. Rosie began wearing custom scarves with her own designs and wanted to share her newfound confidence and joy with other children.

Through her organization, Rosie provides "Smile Kits" to hospitals and charity organizations around the world – including Lurie Children's – for children to create their very own headscarves and superhero capes to wear through their medical journey with a smile.

node.text:
Today's #MoodBoosterMonday congratulates Liam, a teenager who is deaf and has autism spectrum disorder, who wrote and recorded a speech to his fellow 2021 graduates of the Oswego High School – a remarkable milestone given the many obstacles he had to overcome.

Liam, who passed his newborn hearing screening, was diagnosed with major hearing loss at age two. Hearing aids did not help. At age 3 years he received a cochlear implant at Lurie Children’s. In the 15 years since, Liam, who also has Tourette’s syndrome, has had a lot of challenges to overcome when it comes to school and learning. His mom, Angela, credits his hard work and a team of teachers, therapists and staff at his school district and at Lurie Children’s who assisted and encouraged him along the way.

“We want other families to know that the cochlear implant has made a significant difference in Liam's life, especially since he has multiple disabilities,” said Angela. “We feel like without it, he would be stuck in his own little world unable to connect because of his autism and struggling to communicate because of his hearing loss. Liam is a testimony to working hard and achieving a goal.”

node.text:
Knowing that we’ve been able to touch peoples’ lives, that is a gift and privilege that I get to do this as my job.” As the Division Head of Pediatric Neurosurgery, Dr. Sandi Lam is a pioneer in the field of pediatric cerebrovascular surgery and epilepsy surgery.  Each and every day, her understanding and expertise help families to be armed with all the information to make decisions and plans together.

As we continue to honor Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) Heritage Month, and we’re taking an opportunity to highlight members of our world-class team that are making a difference. At Lurie Children’s, we are committed to promoting inclusion so that all members of the Lurie Children’s community feel valued, heard and safe and that every child can realize the promise of a healthier future. #aapiheritagemonth

node.title: Celebrating AAPI Heritage Month: Meet Dr. Sandi Lam

node.text: Meet some of the first 12 to 15-year-olds to receive their first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine at Lurie Children's. Protection from #COVID19 will help prevent the spread in our community and allow us to safely return to school, activities, and normal life. Scheduling your vaccine appointment is simple! Sign up today at luriechildrens.org/vaccine to receive an invitation to schedule an appointment.

node.title: COVID-19 Vaccine | Young Teens Get Vaccinated At Lurie Children's

node.text: Strength can be found in many forms. The nurses of Lurie Children's strength is defined by their actions to accept the call to lead. This strength empowers them to face the challenges of today and prepare for tomorrow. Lurie Children’s nurses never ask how others are leading — they plot the course and create the path for others to follow. On International Nurses Day, we celebrate and honor our nurses who have met the past year with strength, unity and resilience. #nursesweek2021 #internationalnursesday #all4your1

node.text: When Kaleb was only six weeks old, his mother Yessica suspected her partner and Kaleb’s father was physically abusing him. At a local hospital, they found Kaleb had three rib fractures and released him without investigation into the cause of his injuries. Yessica’s case worker recommended Lurie Children’s Child Abuse Pediatrics team, where they found a total of nine rib fractures. “I felt like I had a really strong support system at Lurie Children’s,” his mother shares. Today, Kaleb and his mom remain safe. Yessica is working towards becoming a paralegal so she can continue to advocate for child abuse prevention. During Child Abuse Prevention Month, you have an opportunity to support families like Kaleb's. Tune in to hear his story as part of Milagros por los Niños on @latinomix935 @quebuena1051 @amor1067 and you can help provide healthier futures for kids like Kaleb.

node.title: Support families like Kaleb's during Milagros por los Niños

node.text: On her six-month birthday, Aurora woke up having a seizure. When medications didn't work and the seizures didn't stop, her parents turned to Lurie Children's. Thanks to a minimally invasive brain surgery, Aurora went from having 100 seizures a day to zero. Dr. Sandi Lam, chief of Pediatric Neurosurgery and one of the few surgeons in the world who perform this innovative surgery, shares, "I expect Aurora will be able to walk, run around, go to school and be an active child." While Aurora remains on the road to recovery, she is now a curious, active baby and is learning something new each day.

node.text:
Dr. Nia Heard-Garris is a pediatrician and a physician investigator, examining the impact of racism on children’s health. She also serves as the Chair of the American Academy of Pediatrics’ Minority Health, Equity and Inclusion Committee. "Racism touches on every social determinant of health," shares @drheardgarris, "from economic instability to housing to healthcare, racism magnifies those social determinants."

This #BlackHistoryMonth, we’re highlighting members of our world-class team that are making a difference. At Lurie Children’s, we are committed to promoting inclusion so that all members of the Lurie Children’s community feel valued, heard and safe and that every child can realize the promise of a healthier future.

node.title: Celebrating Black History Month: Meet Dr. Nia Heard-Garris

node.text:
Lurie Children’s first Chief Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Officer Adeola Oduwole and first Associate Chair of Diversity and Inclusion Dr. Valeria Cohran’s leadership is instrumental in leading Lurie Children’s to become a nationally recognized leader in delivering equitable care and achieving equitable outcomes for our patients. That is directly connected to creating an inclusive culture in which everyone – our patients, families and staff – feels safe, respected, valued and have what they need to thrive and be well regardless of their race, ethnicity, social identity or cultural background.

This #BlackHistoryMonth, we’re highlighting members of our world-class team that are making a difference. At Lurie Children’s, we are committed to promoting inclusion so that all members of the Lurie Children’s community feel valued, heard and safe and that every child can realize the promise of a healthier future.

node.title: Celebrating Black History Month: Meet Adeola Oduwole and Dr. Valeria Cohran

node.text:
From a young age, Kiona Allen, MD knew that she wanted to dedicate her life to helping kids. As a pediatric cardiac intensivist and interim medical director of the Regenstein Cardiac Care Unit, Dr. Allen is focused on improving the care, long-term outcome, and quality of life for patients with complex congenital heart disease. Ranked 8th in the nation for child cardiology and heart surgery, the @luriechildrens Heart Center brings the full spectrum of cardiac and neurodevelopmental specialists together to care for patients with the most complex and serious heart conditions.

This #BlackHistoryMonth, we’re highlighting members of our world-class team that are making a difference. At Lurie Children’s, we are committed to promoting inclusion so that all members of the Lurie Children’s community feel valued, heard and safe and that every child can realize the promise of a healthier future. You can learn more about Dr. Allen’s work within the Heart Center at the link in our bio.

node.title: Celebrating Black History Month: Meet Kiona Allen, MD

node.text:
This #EpilepsyAwarenessMonth, we want to share Amelia’s story. When she was only 5 weeks old, Amelia's family came to Lurie Children's to look for a way to control her frequent seizures. Her family had tried several rounds of anti-seizure medication and treatments, but nothing worked. With genetic testing, her team, led by Dr. Millichap, were able to tailor her treatment and reduce her seizures down to zero. 

The nationally prominent Lurie Children’s Epilepsy Center provides comprehensive, multidisciplinary care for children with epilepsy, from evaluation services to specialized epilepsy clinics and epilepsy surgery services. Learn more: https://www.luriechildrens.org/en/specialties-conditions/pediatric-epilepsy/

node.text: We are committed to combating racism and promoting inclusion so that all members of the Lurie Children’s community feel valued, heard and safe and that every child can realize the promise of a healthier future. #whitecoatsforblacklives #all4your1

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lurie Children's on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
Innovative clinical treatments have helped provide healthier futures for kids like Aidan, who battled cancer at age four using aggressive chemotherapy, radiation, surgery and a triple stem cell transplant. Today, he is a healthy college student who is currently on a pre-med track. And for kids like Joe, who has the freedom to play football, go to prom and plan college visits – all thanks to a breakthrough therapy for cystic fibrosis. Of course, none of this would be possible without the support of the Children's Research Fund. 

For 30 years, the @crf_childrensresearchfund has said yes to funding Lurie Children's top researchers. And for 30 years, their support has generated breakthroughs that have focused on improving child health, transforming pediatric medicine and ensuring healthier futures through the relentless pursuit of knowledge. Follow the Children's Research Fund for more stories and ways to support pediatric research.

node.text:
Do have a special Lurie Children's #NICU team member who deserves recognition? Nominate them for the Owl Give Award! 

@jacksonchance11 together with @tiffanyandco is proud to present the 6th Annual Owl Give Award!

Families, patients, and other members of the community have the opportunity to honor a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) team member and say “thank you” for the super-human work they do for patients and their families each day and night.

This award honors them for their courage, compassion, and dedication to improving outcomes for these special babies and their families. Nominate your NICU hero by September 30th by clicking the link in our bio.

Special thanks to Jackson Chance Foundation for providing parking support to our families while their infant is in the NICU. #NICU #Neonatalogy

Nominations are open until Thursday, September 30th!

node.text:
Today's #MoodBoosterMonday celebrates Rosie and the incredible work her not-for-profit foundation, @coming.up.rosies, has done since she and her family founded it five years ago. 

When Rosie was nearly three years old, she was diagnosed with alopecia, an autoimmune disease that attacks hair follicles and prevents hair growth, resulting in baldness. Rosie began wearing custom scarves with her own designs and wanted to share her newfound confidence and joy with other children.

Through her organization, Rosie provides "Smile Kits" to hospitals and charity organizations around the world – including Lurie Children's – for children to create their very own headscarves and superhero capes to wear through their medical journey with a smile.

This Mood Booster Monday is coming to you from Lurie-palooza! 🎶 🎶 🎶 Last week, teen patients got festival ready with salon services and celebrated with DIY flower crown crafts and tie-dye bandanas, karaoke and live music from the official DJ of the Chicago Bulls, DJ Flipside. If you are interested in helping make events like Lurie-palooza possible for our patients and families, please consider visiting our Amazon Wish List at the link in our bio.

The walls of the @anthony_rizzo_familyfoundation Waiting Room on our 18th floor remind patients and families, in the words of @arizz_44, to "stay strong, dream big."

Anthony Rizzo's impact in Chicago has been felt on and off the field. Through the support of the Anthony Rizzo Family Foundation, he has profoundly touched the lives of numerous patients treated for cancer and their families. And throughout the years, the Foundation has committed more than $3.75 million to the hospital, making his impact felt here at Lurie Children's for generations to come.

For everything you have done, Lurie Children's thanks you.

📸: Photos taken pre-COVID-19

node.text:
Facing your grief is an incredible act of courage. After the loss of their son Owen to a brain tumor known as diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma, or DIPG, Amanda and Adam knew they wanted to support families like their own by advocating for pediatric brain tumor research. Pediatric cancer receives only 4 percent of federal research funding. Lurie Children's Pediatric Brain Tumor Research is working harder and faster to discover better treatments that improve the lives of children with brain tumors – but we can’t do it without the support of donors and advocates.

As the family pushes for a cure, Owen’s memory encourages them. “He was a really awesome kid,” Amanda says. “He was really funny and he always made everybody laugh. He was kind and thoughtful and cared deeply about other people – his friends, his siblings, his cousins, his classmates – the list goes on.” Read more at the link in our bio. #all4your1 #braintumorawareness

node.text:
As a volleyball player at Marquette University, Sarah knows the importance of teamwork. This #MoodBoosterMonday, we honor Sarah's latest victory – ringing the end-of-treatment bell and celebrating just outside Lurie Children's with her team of family, friends and supporters. 🔔 

Last September, Sarah’s senior year at Marquette was just beginning when a cancer diagnosis upturned her life. Sarah initially tried to play through the pain in her legs and lower back and saw a doctor when it became unbearable. Scans revealed a tumor on Sarah’s spine, a form of bone cancer known as Ewing sarcoma. She moved home to suburban Chicago to be treated at Lurie Children’s, where a team of pediatric cancer experts had a plan for her.

“My team at Lurie Children’s in the beginning made me feel safe and comfortable,” Sarah said. “They reassured me everything would be OK, that our treatment plan was the best and would get me healthy.” Marquette’s athletic community also rallied for Sarah, who graduated this spring, by wearing gold uniforms to fundraise for pediatric cancer research and welcoming her to the court in February to score an ace at a match. Nine months of chemotherapy and six weeks of radiation later, Sarah rang the end-of-chemo bell with her family and caregivers by her side. “My family supported me every step of the way, and at Marquette it was great to see everybody come together for children everywhere,” she said.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Lurie Children's on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text: We're going for gold! 🏅 With help from our creative Activity Coordinators and volunteers, patients experienced the thrill of the Summer Games from inside the hospital. From archery to soccer and more, patients had the opportunity to earn medals and win prizes. These little athletes prove everyone is golden at the Lurie Children's Olympics. #tokyoolympics #summergames #all4your1

node.text:
Bennett, 4, had been waiting 239 days for a heart for a needed transplant. In June, his mom got the call the family had been waiting for. Today, his story is part of our #MoodBoosterMonday. ❤

Just weeks since his procedure, Bennett is running faster and longer than he has ever been able to, said his mom Danielle. And there’s more that makes Bennett’s transplant remarkable. He was among a hospital record-breaking stretch of heart transplants at Lurie Children’s. In just 48 hours, the cardiovascular-thoracic surgery team performed three heart transplants. Patients Elijah and Logan, both 12, were part of this special group.

The “incredible gift” of organ donation made these life-changing heart transplants possible, said heart surgeon Dr. Michael Mongé, who was a co-surgeon on all three of the transplants. “It is a miracle – it’s the most amazing thing to think you’ve taken a heart, traveled with it, put it in someone who can thrive with it,” Dr. Mongé said. Read more at the link in our bio. #all4your1

node.text:
Have you ever spotted the shark in the Coral Gardens aquarium near the Emergency Department? One patient recently did and sent us this question: what does the shark eat and has it eaten other fish in the aquarium? Our Facilities Services Team shared this answer – just in time to celebrate #SharkWeek: 

"To our future Oceanographer patient,
 
You asked a great question that many of us here at Lurie Children’s ask often. The shark in the Coral Gardens aquarium is a female bamboo shark. She eats mostly shrimp, clams, and small fish called silversides and is fed every Thursday by a trained aquarist/diver. Since she is so well fed and nourished, she doesn't have any interest in eating her tank mates. Bamboo sharks are bottom feeders and have relatively small mouths which are too small to consume many of the fish that are in the tank. Stay hungry for knowledge, it will serve you well!"

node.text:
Back in December, the Andersons became just the third family to undergo an innovative minimally invasive surgery at The Chicago Institute for Fetal Health at Lurie Children’s. 

Dr. Aimen Shaaban, Director of The Chicago Institute, and fetal neurosurgeon Dr. Robin Bowman, repaired the spina bifida defect on Alyssa and Simon’s baby’s back before she was born, putting her on a promising path to avoid spina bifida’s worst symptoms, including immobility and cognitive delays. 

Now almost five months old, Millie has been home for a few months, gaining weight and delighting her parents and big brother, Henry. 

“We are 100% certain we made the right choice for her and our family,” Alyssa said. Watch @fox32news segment about this family’s journey by clicking the link in our profile.

node.text:
Today's #MoodBoosterMonday congratulates Liam, a teenager who is deaf and has autism spectrum disorder, who wrote and recorded a speech to his fellow 2021 graduates of the Oswego High School – a remarkable milestone given the many obstacles he had to overcome.

Liam, who passed his newborn hearing screening, was diagnosed with major hearing loss at age two. Hearing aids did not help. At age 3 years he received a cochlear implant at Lurie Children’s. In the 15 years since, Liam, who also has Tourette’s syndrome, has had a lot of challenges to overcome when it comes to school and learning. His mom, Angela, credits his hard work and a team of teachers, therapists and staff at his school district and at Lurie Children’s who assisted and encouraged him along the way.

“We want other families to know that the cochlear implant has made a significant difference in Liam's life, especially since he has multiple disabilities,” said Angela. “We feel like without it, he would be stuck in his own little world unable to connect because of his autism and struggling to communicate because of his hearing loss. Liam is a testimony to working hard and achieving a goal.”
